resources.string: Understand the air around you, wherever you go with the largest coverage of trusted data.
Something went wrong. Please try again later.

AQI, or Air Quality index, is a system for reporting the severity of air quality levels in relatable terms to the public. The index ranges from 0 to 300+,where high index values indicate higher levels of air pollution and higher potential for adverse health effects. Any value larger than 300, for example, is considered to be hazardous, while an AQI value of 0-50, on the other hand, represents good air quality.
Air quality is considered satisfactory, and air pollution poses little or no risk.
Air quality is acceptable; however, for some pollutants there may be a moderate health concern for a very small number of people who are unusually sensitive to air pollution.
Members of sensitive groups may experience health effects. The general public is not likely to be affected.
Everyone may begin to experience health effects; members of sensitive groups may experience more serious health effects.
Health warnings of emergency conditions. The entire population is more likely to be affected.
Health alert: everyone may experience more serious health effects.

PM2.5 particles are floating particulate matter in the air measuring 2.5 micrometers in diameter or less. PM2.5 is so small it can be absorbed into the bloodstream upon inhalation. For this reason, it is typically the pollutant posing the greatest health treat.
Smoke and soot from wildfires ans waste burning
Vehicular emissions and combustion from motors
Industrial processes involving chemical reactions between gases( sulfur dioxide, nitrogen, oxides, and volatile organic compounds)
Coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath
Respiratory illness such as bronchitis, asthma, emphysema

PM10 is suspended particulate matter in the air with a diameter of 10 micrometers or less. The difference between PM10 ans PM2.5 is simply a matter of size while PM2.5 is fine, PM10 is larger or coarser.
Smoke from wildfires and waste burning

Ozone(O3) is a gas formed by solar ultraviolet radiation (sunlight) and oxygen molecules. Ozone is a naturally occurring compound in the atmosphere that plays a vital role in blocking out harmful UV rays from the sun -at the ground level, however, ozone is toxic.

While other pollutant emitted directly into the air by various sources, ozone is simply created by sunlight acting on nitrogen oxides (NO) and volatile organic compounds (VOC) in the atmoshphere, For this reason, Ozone is the most pervasive and most difficult to control of the six pollutants.
NO2 is a major contributor to the formation of smog and a precursor to many harmful secondary pollutants including ozone and particulate matter.
Organic sources: lightning, plants, water and soil
Inorganic sources: motor vehicle emissions, unfiltered gas heaters, cookers, various industrial activities
Development of asthma and increased risk to experience more frequent and intense asthma attacks

SO2 is colourless gas. It belongs to a group of highly reactive gasses known as the "oxides of sulphur". They easily react together to form harmful compounds such as sulphuric acid, and sulphate particles.
Industrial activity that uses materials containing sulphur to generate electricity
Motor vehicles as a result of fuel combustion

CO known as silent killer, is an odourless, colourless gas. CO reaches dangerous levels when a gas appliance has been incorrectly fitted, badly repaired or poorly maintained, or when flues, chimneys or vents are blocked - thus prohibiting airflow.
Improper operation or poor ventilation of appliances that burn fossil fuels. Sources include fires, fireplaces and stoves,combustion from motor vehicles and power plants.
Oxygen deprivation, headaches, dizziness, drowsiness, weakness
Inhalation prevents blood cells from carrying oxygen
Close your windows to avoid outdoor air
Sensitive groups should wear a mask outdoors
